Symptoms Agitation, anxiety, depression, mania, paranoia, psychosis.SYMPTOM(20,27)mania0.3paranoia0.3depression0.3reactive disorder0.0mild depression0.0disorders0.0post-traumatic stress disorder0.0panic disorder0.0obsessive-compulsive disorder0.0anxiety disorder0.0specific phobias0.0generalized anxiety disorder0.0social anxiety disorder0.0disease0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0disorder0.0personality disorder0.0

A mental disorder, also referred to as a mental illness[5] or psychiatric disorder, is a behavioral or mental pattern that causes significant distress or impairment of personal functioning.[6] Such features may be persistent, relapsing and remitting, or occur as single episodes.SYMPTOM(142,150)mental disorder0.3psychiatric disorder0.3disorder0.3SYMPTOM(154,164)mental disorder0.5psychiatric disorder0.5SYMPTOM(89,99)mental disorder0.2psychiatric disorder0.2disorders0.0gambling addiction0.0disorder0.2mental disorders0.0mental illness0.2

According to DSM-IV, a mental disorder is a psychological syndrome or pattern that is associated with distress (e.g. via a painful symptom), disability (impairment in one or more important areas of functioning), increased risk of death, or causes a significant loss of autonomy; however, it excludes normal responses such as grief from loss of a loved one and also excludes deviant behavior for political, religious, or societal reasons not arising from a dysfunction in the individual.[13].SYMPTOM(141,151)mental health condition0.0mental illness0.0mental disease0.0psychiatric disorder0.0intellectual disability0.0disorders0.0autism0.0mental disorders0.0depression0.0bipolar disorder0.0schizophrenia0.0psychoses0.0dementia0.0mental disorder0.5depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0disorder0.5SYMPTOM(102,110)mental disorder0.5psychiatric disorder0.0disorder0.5SYMPTOM(153,163)mental disorder1.0psychiatric disorder0.0SYMPTOM(346,351)mental disorder1.0SYMPTOM(230,235)mental disorder1.0mental disorders0.0major depression0.0SYMPTOM(123,130)mental disorder1.0SYMPTOM(212,221)mental disorder1.0mental illness0.0disorders0.0schizophrenia0.0delusional disorder0.0mood disorder0.0

Religious, spiritual, or transpersonal experiences and beliefs meet many criteria of delusional or psychotic disorders.[160][161] A belief or experience can sometimes be shown to produce distress or disability—the ordinary standard for judging mental disorders.[162] There is a link between religion and schizophrenia,[163] a complex mental disorder characterized by a difficulty in recognizing reality, regulating emotional responses, and thinking in a clear and logical manner.SYMPTOM(199,209)mental health condition0.0mental illness0.0mental disease0.0psychiatric disorder0.0intellectual disability0.0disorders0.2autism0.0mental disorders0.2depression0.0bipolar disorder0.0schizophrenia0.2psychoses0.0dementia0.0mental disorder0.2depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0disorder0.2SYMPTOM(187,195)mental disorder0.5psychiatric disorder0.0disorder0.5

Many disorders have been described, with signs and symptoms that vary widely between specific disorders.[7][8] Such disorders may be diagnosed by a mental health professional, usually a clinical psychologist or psychiatrist.SYMPTOM(41,59)disorders1.0

In 2019, common mental disorders around the globe include depression, which affects about 264 million, bipolar disorder, which affects about 45 million, dementia, which affects about 50 million, and schizophrenia and other psychoses, which affects about 20 million people.[7] Neurodevelopmental disorders include intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorders which usually arise in infancy or childhood.[11][7] Stigma and discrimination can add to the suffering and disability associated with mental disorders, leading to various social movements attempting to increase understanding and challenge social exclusion. Contents.SYMPTOM(474,484)mental health condition0.0mental illness0.0mental disease0.0psychiatric disorder0.0intellectual disability0.1disorders0.1autism0.1mental disorders0.1depression0.1bipolar disorder0.1schizophrenia0.1psychoses0.1dementia0.1mental disorder0.1depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0disorder0.1SYMPTOM(460,469)intellectual disability0.1disorders0.1autism0.1mental disorders0.1depression0.1bipolar disorder0.1schizophrenia0.1psychoses0.1dementia0.1mental illness0.0mental illnesses0.0SYMPTOM(606,622)intellectual disability0.1disorders0.1autism0.1mental disorders0.1depression0.1bipolar disorder0.1schizophrenia0.1psychoses0.1dementia0.1

For a mental state to classify as a disorder, it generally needs to cause dysfunction.[12] Most international clinical documents use the term mental "disorder", while "illness" is also common.SYMPTOM(6,18)disorder1.0SYMPTOM(168,175)disorder1.0depression0.0mental disorders0.0diseases0.0mental illnesses0.0

In 2013, the American Psychiatric Association (APA) redefined mental disorders in the DSM-5 as "a syndrome characterized by clinically significant disturbance in an individual's cognition, emotion regulation, or behavior that reflects a dysfunction in the psychological, biological, or developmental processes underlying mental functioning.SYMPTOM(226,234)mental disorders1.0

Although "nervous breakdown" is not rigorously defined, surveys of laypersons suggest that the term refers to a specific acute time-limited reactive disorder, involving symptoms such as anxiety or depression, usually precipitated by external stressors.[18] Many health experts today refer to a nervous breakdown as a mental health crisis.[20].SYMPTOM(186,193)mania0.0paranoia0.0depression0.3reactive disorder0.3mild depression0.0disorders0.0post-traumatic stress disorder0.0panic disorder0.0obsessive-compulsive disorder0.0anxiety disorder0.0specific phobias0.0generalized anxiety disorder0.0social anxiety disorder0.0disease0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0disorder0.3personality disorder0.0

We have a package here of five symptoms—mild depression, some anxiety, fatigue, somatic pains, and obsessive thinking. .SYMPTOM(62,69)mania0.0paranoia0.0depression0.5reactive disorder0.0mild depression0.5disorders0.0post-traumatic stress disorder0.0panic disorder0.0obsessive-compulsive disorder0.0anxiety disorder0.0specific phobias0.0generalized anxiety disorder0.0social anxiety disorder0.0disease0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0disorder0.0personality disorder0.0SYMPTOM(80,93)mild depression1.0SYMPTOM(71,78)mild depression0.5depression0.5
There is a deeper illness that drives depression and the symptoms of mood.SYMPTOM(18,25)disorder0.0depression1.0mental disorders0.0diseases0.0mental illnesses0.0

We can call this deeper illness something else, or invent a neologism, but we need to get the discussion off depression and onto this deeper disorder in the brain and body.SYMPTOM(24,31)disorder0.5depression0.5mental disorders0.0diseases0.0mental illnesses0.0SYMPTOM(60,69)depression0.5disorder0.5

In general, mental disorders are classified separately from neurological disorders, learning disabilities or intellectual disability.SYMPTOM(93,105)neurological disorders0.2intellectual disability0.2mental disorders0.2disorder0.2disorders0.2major depression0.0

The high degree of comorbidity between disorders in categorical models such as the DSM and ICD have led some to propose dimensional models.SYMPTOM(4,8)disorders0.5depression0.0disorder0.5mania0.0major depression0.0autism0.0mental disorders0.0mental illness0.0mental disorder0.0

The disorders associated with most disabilities in high-income countries were unipolar major depression (20%) and alcohol use disorder (11%).SYMPTOM(35,47)neurological disorders0.0intellectual disability0.0mental disorders0.0disorder0.3disorders0.3major depression0.3SYMPTOM(51,55)disorders0.2depression0.2disorder0.2mania0.0major depression0.2autism0.0mental disorders0.0mental illness0.0mental disorder0.0

Studying comorbidity between disorders have demonstrated two latent (unobserved) factors or dimensions in the structure of mental disorders that are thought to possibly reflect etiological processes.SYMPTOM(169,176)mental disorders0.5disorders0.5

These two dimensions reflect a distinction between internalizing disorders, such as mood or anxiety symptoms, and externalizing disorders such as behavioral or substance use symptoms.[31] A single general factor of psychopathology, similar to the g factor for intelligence, has been empirically supported.SYMPTOM(92,99)mania0.0paranoia0.0depression0.0reactive disorder0.0mild depression0.0disorders0.5post-traumatic stress disorder0.0panic disorder0.0obsessive-compulsive disorder0.0anxiety disorder0.0specific phobias0.0generalized anxiety disorder0.0social anxiety disorder0.0disease0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0disorder0.5personality disorder0.0SYMPTOM(146,156)mental disorder0.0psychiatric disorder0.0disorders0.5gambling addiction0.0disorder0.5mental disorders0.0mental illness0.0SYMPTOM(21,28)mental disorders0.0disorders1.0

Antidepressants are used for the treatment of clinical depression, as well as often for anxiety and a range of other disorders.SYMPTOM(88,95)mania0.0paranoia0.0depression0.3reactive disorder0.0mild depression0.0disorders0.3post-traumatic stress disorder0.0panic disorder0.0obsessive-compulsive disorder0.0anxiety disorder0.0specific phobias0.0generalized anxiety disorder0.0social anxiety disorder0.0disease0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0disorder0.3personality disorder0.0

The p factor model supports the internalizing-externalizing distinction, but also supports the formation of a third dimension of thought disorders such as schizophrenia.[32] Biological evidence also supports the validity of the internalizing-externalizing structure of mental disorders, with twin and adoption studies supporting heritable factors for externalizing and internalizing disorders.[33][34][35] A leading dimensional model is the Hierarchical Taxonomy of Psychopathology.SYMPTOM(301,309)disorders0.5mental disorders0.5

An anxiety disorder is anxiety or fear that interferes with normal functioning may be classified as an anxiety disorder.[37] Commonly recognized categories include specific phobias, generalized anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, panic disorder, agoraphobia, obsessive-compulsive disorder and post-traumatic stress disorder.SYMPTOM(23,30)mania0.0paranoia0.0depression0.0reactive disorder0.0mild depression0.0disorders0.0post-traumatic stress disorder0.1panic disorder0.1obsessive-compulsive disorder0.1anxiety disorder0.1specific phobias0.1generalized anxiety disorder0.1social anxiety disorder0.1disease0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0disorder0.1personality disorder0.0SYMPTOM(103,110)mania0.0paranoia0.0depression0.0reactive disorder0.0mild depression0.0disorders0.0post-traumatic stress disorder0.1panic disorder0.1obsessive-compulsive disorder0.1anxiety disorder0.1specific phobias0.1generalized anxiety disorder0.1social anxiety disorder0.1disease0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0disorder0.1personality disorder0.0SYMPTOM(253,264)post-traumatic stress disorder0.1panic disorder0.1obsessive-compulsive disorder0.1anxiety disorder0.1specific phobias0.1generalized anxiety disorder0.1social anxiety disorder0.1SYMPTOM(34,38)post-traumatic stress disorder0.1panic disorder0.1obsessive-compulsive disorder0.1anxiety disorder0.1specific phobias0.1generalized anxiety disorder0.1social anxiety disorder0.1personality disorders0.0obsessive-compulsive personality0.0disorders0.0

Mood disorder involving unusually intense and sustained sadness, melancholia, or despair is known as major depression (also known as unipolar or clinical depression).SYMPTOM(81,88)depression0.3major depression0.3disorder0.3

Bipolar disorder (also known as manic depression) involves abnormally "high" or pressured mood states, known as mania or hypomania, alternating with normal or depressed moods.SYMPTOM(71,75)disorders0.0depression0.3disorder0.3mania0.3major depression0.0autism0.0mental disorders0.0mental illness0.0mental disorder0.0SYMPTOM(121,130)depression0.3disorder0.3mania0.3SYMPTOM(32,37)depression0.3disorder0.3mania0.3

Patterns of belief, language use and perception of reality can become dysregulated (e.g., delusions, thought disorder, hallucinations).SYMPTOM(90,99)disorder1.0disorders0.0schizophrenia0.0delusional disorder0.0mood disorder0.0SYMPTOM(119,133)disorder1.0disorders0.0schizophrenia0.0delusional disorder0.0mood disorder0.0

A number of different personality disorders are listed, including those sometimes classed as eccentric, such as paranoid, schizoid and schizotypal personality disorders; types that have described as dramatic or emotional, such as antisocial, borderline, histrionic or narcissistic personality disorders; and those sometimes classed as fear-related, such as anxious-avoidant, dependent, or obsessive-compulsive personality disorders.SYMPTOM(335,339)post-traumatic stress disorder0.0panic disorder0.0obsessive-compulsive disorder0.0anxiety disorder0.0specific phobias0.0generalized anxiety disorder0.0social anxiety disorder0.0personality disorders0.3obsessive-compulsive personality0.3disorders0.3SYMPTOM(357,364)personality disorders0.3obsessive-compulsive personality0.3disorders0.3SYMPTOM(230,240)personality disorders0.3obsessive-compulsive personality0.3disorders0.3SYMPTOM(340,347)personality disorders0.2obsessive-compulsive personality0.2disorders0.2disorder0.2mental disorders0.0insomnia0.0anxiety disorders0.0depression0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0personality disorder0.2mental illness0.0

Personality disorders, in general, are defined as emerging in childhood, or at least by adolescence or early adulthood.SYMPTOM(88,99)disorders1.0anxiety disorders0.0mood disorders0.0schizophrenia0.0SYMPTOM(62,71)disorders0.5disorder0.5anxiety disorders0.0schizophrenia0.0bipolar disorder0.0conduct disorder0.0antisocial personality disorder0.0psychopathy0.0

Some other anxiety disorders, substance disorders, and mood disorders emerge later in the mid-teens.[51] Symptoms of schizophrenia typically manifest from late adolescence to early twenties.[52].SYMPTOM(160,171)disorders0.2anxiety disorders0.2mood disorders0.2schizophrenia0.2

There is an emerging consensus that personality disorders, similar to personality traits in general, incorporate a mixture of acute dysfunctional behaviors that may resolve in short periods, and maladaptive temperamental traits that are more enduring.[42]SYMPTOM(176,189)personality disorders1.0SYMPTOM(70,88)personality disorders1.0SYMPTOM(207,220)personality disorders1.0

Eating disorders involve disproportionate concern in matters of food and weight.[37] Categories of disorder in this area include anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, exercise bulimia or binge eating disorder.[44][45].SYMPTOM(129,137)nervosa, bulimia0.2disorders0.2disorder0.2bulimia0.2SYMPTOM(184,196)nervosa, bulimia0.2disorders0.2disorder0.2bulimia0.2
A common sleep disorder is insomnia, which is described as difficulty falling and/or staying asleep.SYMPTOM(70,77)insomnia0.5sleep disorder0.5SYMPTOM(93,99)insomnia0.5sleep disorder0.5

Other sleep disorders include narcolepsy, sleep apnea, REM sleep behavior disorder, chronic sleep deprivation, and restless leg syndrome.SYMPTOM(59,73)sleep apnea0.2restless leg syndrome0.2disorder0.2narcolepsy0.2sleep disorders0.2SYMPTOM(92,109)sleep apnea0.2restless leg syndrome0.2disorder0.2narcolepsy0.2sleep disorders0.2
People with narcolepsy feel refreshed after their random sleep, but eventually get sleepy again.SYMPTOM(83,89)narcolepsy1.0
Sleep apnea, when breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep, can be a serious sleep disorder.SYMPTOM(6,11)sleep disorder1.0sleep apnea0.0central sleep apnea0.0

Three types of sleep apnea include obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea, and complex sleep apnea.[47] Sleep apnea can be diagnosed at home or with polysomnography at a sleep center.SYMPTOM(116,121)sleep disorder0.0sleep apnea0.5central sleep apnea0.5

Sexual disorders include dyspareunia and various kinds of paraphilia (sexual arousal to objects, situations, or individuals that are considered abnormal or harmful to the person or others).SYMPTOM(25,36)paraphilia0.5disorders0.5SYMPTOM(70,84)paraphilia0.5disorders0.5

Impulse control disorder: People who are abnormally unable to resist certain urges or impulses that could be harmful to themselves or others, may be classified as having an impulse control disorder, and disorders such as kleptomania (stealing) or pyromania (fire-setting).SYMPTOM(234,242)kleptomania0.2disorders0.2disorder0.2impulse control disorder0.2pyromania0.2

Various behavioral addictions, such as gambling addiction, may be classed as a disorder.SYMPTOM(8,18)mental disorder0.0psychiatric disorder0.0disorders0.0gambling addiction0.5disorder0.5mental disorders0.0mental illness0.0SYMPTOM(19,29)gambling addiction0.5disorder0.5

This disorder refers to the use of drugs (legal or illegal, including alcohol) that persists despite significant problems or harm related to its use.SYMPTOM(130,137)personality disorders0.0obsessive-compulsive personality0.0disorders0.0disorder1.0mental disorders0.0insomnia0.0anxiety disorders0.0depression0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0personality disorder0.0mental illness0.0

The likely course and outcome of mental disorders vary and are dependent on numerous factors related to the disorder itself, the individual as a whole, and the social environment.SYMPTOM(93,100)personality disorders0.0obsessive-compulsive personality0.0disorders0.3disorder0.3mental disorders0.3insomnia0.0anxiety disorders0.0depression0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0personality disorder0.0mental illness0.0

Disorders such as depression, anxiety, schizophrenia, personality disorder, old age-related disorder, and substance-abuse disorder are common in Nigeria, as in other countries in Africa.[148].SYMPTOM(30,37)mania0.0paranoia0.0depression0.2reactive disorder0.0mild depression0.0disorders0.0post-traumatic stress disorder0.0panic disorder0.0obsessive-compulsive disorder0.0anxiety disorder0.0specific phobias0.0generalized anxiety disorder0.0social anxiety disorder0.0disease0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.2abuse0.2disorder0.2personality disorder0.2SYMPTOM(84,91)personality disorders0.0obsessive-compulsive personality0.0disorders0.0disorder0.2mental disorders0.0insomnia0.0anxiety disorders0.0depression0.2schizophrenia0.2abuse0.2personality disorder0.2mental illness0.0SYMPTOM(76,83)depression0.2schizophrenia0.2abuse0.2disorder0.2personality disorder0.2
Substance dependence and substance abuse fall under this umbrella category in the DSM.SYMPTOM(41,45)substance abuse1.0

Substance use disorder may be due to a pattern of compulsive and repetitive use of a drug that results in tolerance to its effects and withdrawal symptoms when use is reduced or stopped.SYMPTOM(135,154)disorder1.0

Developmental disorder: These disorders initially occur in childhood.SYMPTOM(59,68)disorders0.5disorder0.5anxiety disorders0.0schizophrenia0.0bipolar disorder0.0conduct disorder0.0antisocial personality disorder0.0psychopathy0.0

Some examples include autism spectrum disorder, oppositional defiant disorder and conduct disorder, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which may continue into adulthood.SYMPTOM(122,135)autism0.2disorder0.2oppositional defiant disorder0.2conduct disorder0.2

Neurasthenia is an old diagnosis involving somatic complaints as well as fatigue and low spirits/depression, which is officially recognized by the ICD-10 but no longer by the DSM-IV.[48][non-primary source needed].SYMPTOM(73,80)mild depression0.0depression1.0SYMPTOM(51,61)depression1.0

There already exists, under the category of psychosis, a diagnosis of shared psychotic disorder where two or more individuals share a particular delusion because of their close relationship with each other.SYMPTOM(145,153)shared psychotic disorder1.0disorders0.0

There are a number of uncommon psychiatric syndromes, which are often named after the person who first described them, such as Capgras syndrome, De Clerambault syndrome, Othello syndrome, Ganser syndrome, Cotard delusion, and Ekbom syndrome, and additional disorders such as the Couvade syndrome and Geschwind syndrome.[49].SYMPTOM(212,220)shared psychotic disorder0.0disorders1.0

The onset of psychiatric disorders usually occurs from childhood to early adulthood.[50] Impulse-control disorders and a few anxiety disorders tend to appear in childhood.SYMPTOM(55,64)disorders0.3disorder0.3anxiety disorders0.3schizophrenia0.0bipolar disorder0.0conduct disorder0.0antisocial personality disorder0.0psychopathy0.0SYMPTOM(161,170)disorders0.3disorder0.3anxiety disorders0.3schizophrenia0.0bipolar disorder0.0conduct disorder0.0antisocial personality disorder0.0psychopathy0.0SYMPTOM(13,34)disorders0.5anxiety disorders0.5depression0.0
Some disorders may last a brief period of time, while others may be long-term in nature.SYMPTOM(26,38)disorders1.0

A follow-up study by Tohen and coworkers revealed that around half of people initially diagnosed with bipolar disorder achieve symptomatic recovery (no longer meeting criteria for the diagnosis) within six weeks, and nearly all achieve it within two years, with nearly half regaining their prior occupational and residential status in that period.SYMPTOM(2,11)bipolar disorder1.0
Post-traumatic stress disorder 3.5 million.SYMPTOM(15,21)disorder1.0abuse0.0bipolar disorder0.0depression0.0disease0.0diabetes0.0disorders0.0mental disorders0.0

It is also the case that, while often being characterized in purely negative terms, some mental traits or states labeled as disorders can also involve above-average creativity, non-conformity, goal-striving, meticulousness, or empathy.[58] In addition, the public perception of the level of disability associated with mental disorders can change.[59].SYMPTOM(291,301)mental health condition0.0mental illness0.0mental disease0.0psychiatric disorder0.0intellectual disability0.0disorders0.2autism0.0mental disorders0.2depression0.0bipolar disorder0.0schizophrenia0.0psychoses0.0dementia0.0mental disorder0.2depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0disorder0.2SYMPTOM(165,175)mental disorders0.5disorders0.5

The proportion with access to professional help for mental disorders is far lower, however, even among those assessed as having a severely disabling condition.[60] Disability in this context may or may not involve such things as In terms of total disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), which is an estimate of how many years of life are lost due to premature death or to being in a state of poor health and disability, mental disorders rank amongst the most disabling conditions.SYMPTOM(247,257)mental health condition0.0mental illness0.0mental disease0.0psychiatric disorder0.0intellectual disability0.0disorders0.2autism0.0mental disorders0.2depression0.0bipolar disorder0.0schizophrenia0.0psychoses0.0dementia0.0mental disorder0.2depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0disorder0.2SYMPTOM(408,418)mental health condition0.0mental illness0.0mental disease0.0psychiatric disorder0.0intellectual disability0.0disorders0.2autism0.0mental disorders0.2depression0.0bipolar disorder0.0schizophrenia0.0psychoses0.0dementia0.0mental disorder0.2depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0disorder0.2SYMPTOM(360,365)mental disorder0.5mental disorders0.5major depression0.0

Unipolar (also known as Major) depressive disorder is the third leading cause of disability worldwide, of any condition mental or physical, accounting for 65.5 million years lost.SYMPTOM(81,91)mental health condition0.0mental illness0.0mental disease0.0psychiatric disorder0.0intellectual disability0.0disorders0.0autism0.0mental disorders0.0depression0.0bipolar disorder0.0schizophrenia0.0psychoses0.0dementia0.0mental disorder0.0depressive disorder0.5communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0disorder0.5

Second to this were accidental injuries (mainly traffic collisions) accounting for 12 percent of disability, followed by communicable diseases at 10 percent.SYMPTOM(97,107)mental health condition0.0mental illness0.0mental disease0.0psychiatric disorder0.0intellectual disability0.0disorders0.0autism0.0mental disorders0.0depression0.0bipolar disorder0.0schizophrenia0.0psychoses0.0dementia0.0mental disorder0.0depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.5accidental injuries0.5disorder0.0

A number of psychiatric disorders are linked to a family history (including depression, narcissistic personality disorder[67][68] and anxiety).[69]SYMPTOM(12,33)disorders0.5anxiety disorders0.0depression0.5SYMPTOM(50,64)depression1.0

Twin studies have also revealed a very high heritability for many mental disorders (especially autism and schizophrenia).[70]SYMPTOM(39,43)disorders0.2depression0.0disorder0.2mania0.0major depression0.0autism0.2mental disorders0.2mental illness0.0mental disorder0.2

Social influences have also been found to be important,[74] including abuse, neglect, bullying, social stress, traumatic events, and other negative or overwhelming life experiences.SYMPTOM(103,109)disorder0.0abuse1.0bipolar disorder0.0depression0.0disease0.0diabetes0.0disorders0.0mental disorders0.0SYMPTOM(86,94)abuse1.0SYMPTOM(77,84)abuse1.0

Mental illnesses were well known in ancient Mesopotamia,[141] where diseases and mental disorders were believed to be caused by specific deities.[142] Because hands symbolized control over a person, mental illnesses were known as "hands" of certain deities.[142] One psychological illness was known as Qāt Ištar, meaning "Hand of Ishtar".[142] Others were known as "Hand of Shamash", "Hand of the Ghost", and "Hand of the God".[142]SYMPTOM(281,288)disorder0.2depression0.0mental disorders0.2diseases0.2mental illnesses0.2SYMPTOM(7,16)diseases0.2disease0.2mental disorders0.2mental illnesses0.2

Media coverage of mental illness comprises predominantly negative and pejorative depictions, for example, of incompetence, violence or criminality, with far less coverage of positive issues such as accomplishments or human rights issues.[202][203][204] Such negative depictions, including in children's cartoons, are thought to contribute to stigma and negative attitudes in the public and in those with mental health problems themselves, although more sensitive or serious cinematic portrayals have increased in prevalence.[205][206].SYMPTOM(500,509)mental disorder0.0mental illness1.0disorders0.0schizophrenia0.0delusional disorder0.0mood disorder0.0SYMPTOM(342,348)stereotypes0.0mental illness1.0SYMPTOM(135,146)mental illness1.0SYMPTOM(292,300)mental illness1.0

Despite public or media opinion, national studies have indicated that severe mental illness does not independently predict future violent behavior, on average, and is not a leading cause of violence in society.SYMPTOM(130,146)mental illness1.0

In a study of individuals diagnosed with "severe mental illness" living in a US inner-city area, a quarter were found to have been victims of at least one violent crime over the course of a year, a proportion eleven times higher than the inner-city average, and higher in every category of crime including violent assaults and theft.[222] People with a diagnosis may find it more difficult to secure prosecutions, however, due in part to prejudice and being seen as less credible.[223].SYMPTOM(438,447)mental illness1.0

High-profile cases have led to fears that serious crimes, such as homicide, have increased due to deinstitutionalization, but the evidence does not support this conclusion.[225][226] Violence that does occur in relation to mental disorder (against the mentally ill or by the mentally ill) typically occurs in the context of complex social interactions, often in a family setting rather than between strangers.[227] It is also an issue in health care settings[228] and the wider community.[229].SYMPTOM(81,90)mental disorder1.0mental illness0.0disorders0.0schizophrenia0.0delusional disorder0.0mood disorder0.0SYMPTOM(261,264)mental disorders0.0mental illnesses0.0stereotypes0.0mental disorder1.0SYMPTOM(284,287)mental disorders0.0mental illnesses0.0stereotypes0.0mental disorder1.0SYMPTOM(31,36)mental disorder1.0

According to the World Health Organization, over a third of people in most countries report problems at some time in their life which meet the criteria for diagnosis of one or more of the common types of mental disorder.[126] Corey M Keyes has created a two continua model of mental illness and health which holds that both are related, but distinct dimensions: one continuum indicates the presence or absence of mental health, the other the presence or absence of mental illness.[230] For example, people with optimal mental health can also have a mental illness, and people who have no mental illness can also have poor mental health.[231].SYMPTOM(328,335)personality disorders0.0obsessive-compulsive personality0.0disorders0.0disorder0.5mental disorders0.0insomnia0.0anxiety disorders0.0depression0.0schizophrenia0.0abuse0.0personality disorder0.0mental illness0.5
